answers.body_markdown:
In the `for` loop you are comparing the property `getCn()` in `LdapRoles`, But while using `stream` you are comparing the object which is `LdapRoles`  So if you want common data by comparing property `getCn()`  use `anyMatch`

    List<LdapRoles> common = ldpaRoleldpaRoleList1.stream()
                                           .filter(list->list2.stream().anyMatch(i2->i2.getCn().equals(list.getCn()))
                                           .collect(Collectors.toList());

ANd if you want uncomman data use `noneMatch`

    List<LdapRoles> common = ldpaRoleldpaRoleList1.stream()
                                           .filter(list->list2.stream().noneMatch(i2->i2.getCn().equals(list.getCn()))
                                           .collect(Collectors.toList());

Or you can use `Collectors.partitioningBy`

     Map<Boolean, List<LdapRoles>> common = ldpaRoleldpaRoleList1.stream()
                                          .collect(Collectors.partitioningBy(item->list2.stream().anyMatch(i2->i2.getCn().equals(item.getCn())));

answers.body_markdown:
[POSIX.1-2017][1] remarks that `system()` call 'need not be thread-safe'.

Generally speaking, calling `system()` in a multithread environment is not a good idea. The purpose of the function is like "run a secondary process and wait for it to finish". That's why the signals are trapped and blocked.

If you expect your main process to be killed somehow (eg. by pressing Ctrl+C) perhaps you would prefer to use `popen()` instead.


  [1]: https://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/functions/system.html#tag_16_597_03
answers.title: SIGINT ignored while calling system(3)

answers.body_markdown:
If I understand you correctly, you want to find all users, excluding contractors, but including contractors in the exception group.

I think you're looking for:

- The `!` operator, which means "not", and
- The `|` operator, which means "or":

Like this:

    (&(objectClass=user)
      (|(!memberOf=CN=Contractors,CN=Users,DC=XYZ,DC=com) 
      (memberOf=CN=Exception_Contractors,OU=File Server Groups,OU=GRP,OU=XYZ,DC=INC,DC=com)))

So that means: all users who are either not in the contractors group or are in the exception contractors group.

On a side note, `objectClass=user` isn't a "group". It just means "all user objects". (as opposed to computer, contact, OU objects, etc.)

    function(build_shader TARGETOBJ SHADERNAME)

I am cleaning a local git repo with a lot of large tarballs in the history. I did the following steps:

1. List the all the tarball files in the repo

```
FILE_LIST=`git rev-list master | while read rev; do git ls-tree -lr $rev  | cut -c54- | sed 's/^ +//g;'; done | grep <tarball name> | awk '{print $2}' | sort | uniq | tr '\n' ' '`
```

2. Mark them for deletion

```
git filter-branch --tag-name-filter cat --index-filter "git rm -r --cached --ignore-unmatch $FILE_LIST" --prune-empty -f -- --all
```

3. Garbage collection

```
rm -rf .git/refs/original/ && git reflog expire --expire=now --all && git gc --aggressive --prune=now
```

4. Push

```
git push origin --force --all && git push origin --force --tags
```

By doing this I reduced the size of the local repo significantly. However, when I got a clean clone from the origin after the above steps, the size of the cloned repo is not reduced, but those large tarballs are gone by verifying

I did the garbage collection step again in the cloned repo, the size was not reduced.

answers.body_markdown:
May I suggest an alternative? Using `pathlib` and it's `rglob` method, everything is much easier (if you really are agnostic about subdirectories):

    from pathlib import Path

    def cmp_file_lists(dir1, dir2):
        dir1_filenames = set(f.name for f in Path(dir1).rglob('*'))
        dir2_filenames = set(f.name for f in Path(dir2).rglob('*'))
        files_in_dir1_but_not_dir2 = dir1_filenames - dir2_filenames 
        files_in_dir2_but_not_dir1 = dir2_filenames - dir1_filenames 
        return dir1_filenames, dir2_filenames

Something I don't understand appears in apache2. If I look to the server-status page, I see a bunch of [workers][1] stuck in a read state, with the request being the NULL request.
After the [Timeout][2] of apache2 is reached, the worker is killed and no timeout error (408) is sent to the client, which makes sense since the client is not even making a request..

Apache/2.4.18 (Ubuntu). mod_jk/1.2.43. Tomcat7. IPVS and Keepalived.

Thanks,

Paul.

answers.body_markdown:
I think that you are using 127.0.0.1 incorrectly. Even if you are on the same machine, each container has its own 127.0.0.1, which is different from the host's localhost.

I don't really understand your setup and the port redirections you have, but say that you have two containers A (producer) and B (consumer), you will have to access `rtsp://A:5004/` (you can use the container name as I did)

answers.body_markdown:
As per the [Expression Attribute Name documentation][1]

> An expression attribute name is a placeholder that you use in an
> Amazon DynamoDB expression as an alternative to an actual attribute
> name. An expression attribute name must begin with a pound sign (#),
> and be followed by one or more alphanumeric characters.


I think you are missing the pound(#) in from of your placeholder attribute names. 

Try to change this 

    attr_names = {'status_name': 'status'}

to

    attr_names = {'#status_name': 'status'}


  [1]: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/Expressions.ExpressionAttributeNames.html

answers.body_markdown:
From the socket(7) manual page

>        SO_RCVTIMEO and SO_SNDTIMEO
              Specify  the  receiving or sending timeouts until reporting an error.  The argument
              is a struct timeval.  If an input or output function  blocks  for  this  period  of
              time, and data has been sent or received, the return value of that function will be
              the amount of data transferred; if no data has been transferred and the timeout has
              been  reached, then -1 is returned with errno set to EAGAIN or EWOULDBLOCK, or EIN‐
              PROGRESS (for connect(2)) just as if the socket was specified  to  be  nonblocking.
              If the timeout is set to zero (the default), then the operation will never timeout.
              Timeouts only have effect for system calls that perform socket I/O (e.g.,  read(2),
              recvmsg(2),  send(2),  sendmsg(2)); timeouts have no effect for select(2), poll(2),
              epoll_wait(2), and so on.

so by setting a timeout you may get an EAGAIN/EINPROGRESS result if the timeout expires.
answers.title: Linux kernel bug? Create new socket defaults to non blocking

items.body_markdown:
Say we use TensorFlow r2.0 and say we want to use sub-models in Keras, so we have a model **A** like this:

```python
def create_model_A(in_num_units, name):
    x = tf.keras.Input(shape=(in_num_units))
    y = tf.keras.layers.Dense(in_num_units, activation='relu')(x)
    y = tf.keras.layers.BatchNormalization()(y)
    y = tf.keras.layers.Dense(in_num_units, activation='relu')(y)
    y = tf.keras.layers.BatchNormalization()(y)
    y = x + y
    return tf.keras.Model(x, y, name=name)
```

and model **B** that makes use of model **A**:

```python
def create_model_B(in_num_units):
    x = tf.keras.Input(shape=(in_num_units))
    y = create_model_A(x.shape[-1], name='A_1')(x)
    y = tf.keras.layers.Dense(in_num_units // 2, name='downsize_1')(y)
    y = tf.keras.layers.BatchNormalization()(y)
    y = create_model_A(y.shape[-1], name='A_2')(y)
    y = tf.keras.layers.Dense(in_num_units // 2, name='downsize_2')(y)
    y = tf.keras.layers.BatchNormalization()(y)
    y = create_model_A(y.shape[-1], name='A_3')(y)
    y = tf.keras.layers.Dense(in_num_units // 2, name='downsize_3')(y)
    y = tf.keras.layers.BatchNormalization()(y)
    y = create_model_A(y.shape[-1], name='A_4')(y)
    return tf.keras.Model(x, y)
```

This works like a charm. We can instantiate a model **B** like this:

```python
num_in_units = 500
model = create_model_B(num_in_units) # Works!
```

And benefit from all the advantages of a tf.keras.Model. But, the problem arises when we want to obtain the result of an intermediate layer that is of sub-model *A*. If the layer is part of model **B**, everything work:

```python
inter_model_1 = tf.keras.Model(
    model.input, model.get_layer('downsize_1').output) # Works!
```

But if the layer is of sub-model A:

```python
inter_model_2 = tf.keras.Model(
    model.input, model.get_layer('A_3').output) # Does not work!
```

This crashes with the error:

```shell
ValueError: Graph disconnected: cannot obtain value for tensor Tensor("input_4:0", shape=(None, 250), dtype=float32) at layer "input_4". The following previous layers were accessed without issue: [] 
```

I'm not sure I understand all the inside mechanics of keras. But what I understand when I dove in the source code, is that sub-models used this way have two input tensors object created. They can be printed like this:


```python
print([n.input_tensors.name for n in model.get_layer('A_3').inbound_nodes])
```

This yields:

```shell
['input_4:0', 'batch_normalization_5/Identity:0']
```

One is the sub-model `tf.keras.Input` and the other one is the input linked to the top-model. 

When building a new model from a top-model **B** input tensor to a top-model **B** output tensor, the path in the graph seems to correctly pass by the `'batch_normalization_5'` input and both tensors are correctly connected in the graph.
 
However, when trying to link a top-model **B** input tensor to a sub-model **A** output tensor, the output tensors seems to be connected to the sub-model tf.keras.Input adn the path and both tensors are then disconnected.

A solution I found at the moment is to use the top-model version of the tensor ```model.get_layer('A_3').output```:

```python
model.get_layer('A_3')._outbound_nodes[0].input_tensors
```

But this seems overcomplicated and not clean... In addition, it does not let us make use of the layers inside model **A**.

I wonder if someone could give me some precision on this particular `tf.keras` behavior. Am I right to do so? Is this the intended behavior? Is this a bug? Thanks a lot!
items.title: Cannot obtain the output of intermediate sub-model layers with tf2.0/keras

Well, there are two problems in your question.

 1. How to calculate a shortest route from point A to point B.
 2. How to draw the route.

The first problem is the [shortest path problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shortest_path_problem) and could be solved with the appropriate algorithms from [graph theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_theory).

Drawing the route should be a trivial problem after you solve the first one.

I quickly googled for some existing solutions and here is what I found:

 - https://github.com/lettier/shortestpath
 - https://js.cytoscape.org

answers.body_markdown:
You can use a simple `NOT IN` to achieve your desired result (assuming `id` as the unique identifier in `devices`, `device_id` as the foreign key to `devices.id` within `tests`, and `tests.device_id` has a `NOT NULL` attribute:

    SELECT *
    FROM devices
    WHERE id NOT IN (
        SELECT DISTINCT device_id
        FROM tests
    );

This should work across most major RDBMS'; since you haven't specified which one you're using, your mileage may vary.
answers.title: Oracle SQL: Check if entry exists and return if it DOESN'T

answers.body_markdown:
> So what I want to SELECT is all entries in devices that are NOT referenced by at least one entry in tests.

Assuming the following data structures:

	devices(id)
	tests(id, device_id)

You could use `not exists`:

	select d.*
	from devices
	where not exists (
		select 1
		from tests t
		where t.device_id = d.id
	)

Or a left join antipattern:

	select d.*
	from devices d
	left join tests t on t.device_id = d.id
	where t.id is null
answers.title: Oracle SQL: Check if entry exists and return if it DOESN'T

answers.body_markdown:
Thanks, that worked. I'll admit, I changed the names of my tables above to make it easier to ask the question, but here's what I concluded with and it's working correctly:

    SELECT DEVICE.ID
    FROM DEVICE
    WHERE DEVICE.ID NOT IN (
    SELECT TEST.DEVICEID FROM TEST WHERE TEST.DEVICEID=DEVICE.ID)
    ORDER BY DEVICE.ID

Simple in the end. Can't tell I'm a beginner at SQL, can you? :)
answers.title: Oracle SQL: Check if entry exists and return if it DOESN'T
